content.description: A planet has two moons, Moon <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and Moon <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, that orbit at different distances from the planet’s center, as shown. Astronomers collect data regarding the planet, the two moons, and their obits. The astronomers are able to estimate the planet’s radius and mass.
content.question: The masses of the two moons are determined to be <math alttext="2 uppercase M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for Moon <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="uppercase M" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for Moon <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. It is observed that the distance between Moon <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and the planet is two times that of the distance between Moon <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and the planet. How does force exerted from the planet on Moon <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> compare to the force exerted from the planet on Moon <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>B</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

choices.label: The gravitational force exerted from the planet on Moon <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is two times larger than the gravitational force exerted from the planet on Moon <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>B</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> .

The gravitational force exerted from the planet on Moon <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is eight times larger than the gravitational force exerted from the planet on Moon <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>B</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> .

The gravitational force exerted from the planet on Moon <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is two times smaller than the gravitational force exerted from the planet on Moon <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>B</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> .

The gravitational force exerted from the planet on Moon <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is eight times smaller than the gravitational force exerted from the planet on Moon <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>B</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> .

content.answer: The gravitational force exerted from the planet on Moon <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is eight times larger than the gravitational force exerted from the planet on Moon <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>B</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> .

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
